title: Ticket #1253: condor_negotiator ran out of fds
description:
The gist of the problem, from the ticket: 

Below is an excerpt from yesterday's NegotiatorLog on the Condor central
manager at LHO.  Rest of log is available, if needed.  Cluster consists
of 250 machines, 2000 slots, running CentOS 5.3, Condor 7.4.1 and there
were 5000+ jobs being negotiated at the time.  Negotiator was still
working its way through the first 1000 before running out of FDs.  I've
since increased "nofile" from the default 1024 in
/etc/security/limits.conf, and all seems fine.

My question is, were there more than 1024 slots open for which the negotiator was negotiating? How many fds should the negotiator consume in normal operation? Is there a nonblocking tcp connect to each slot when looking for a match? Should we recommend the fd limits for negotiation machines be increased?
remarks:
2010-Jun-16 00:31:10 by matt:
My question is, were there more than 1024 slots open for which the negotiator was negotiating?

Most likely, possibly 2000

How many fds should the negotiator consume in normal operation?

One for Collector (get ads), one per schedd (or submitter?) (get jobs), one per match (notify slot)

Is there a nonblocking tcp connect to each slot when looking for a match?

Yes, when a match occurs

Should we recommend the fd limits for negotiation machines be increased?

Yes

We should also consider queueing the slot notification instead of queueing the open TCP connection -- self draining queue anyone?
